channel.title: Can some1 explain this to me?

item.title: Can some1 explain this to me?
item.dc:creator: @xx_matty_xx Justin Bieber
item.description:
@xx_matty_xx wrote:

just to simplify your code a bit…

public void giveTask() {
      if (c.combatLevel < 50)
         giveTask(1);
      else if (c.combatLevel <= 90)
         giveTask(2);
      else if (c.combatLevel <= 121)
         giveTask(3);
      else if (c.combatLevel <= 138)
         giveTask(4);
      else
         giveTask(2);   
   }

i’m pretty sure all of those extra checks were redundant, so this should make yo code block a bit easier to understand. it might also make it faster depending on how good the compiler was at optimising it before, but i’m not really a compiler/optimisation guy so can’t make any promises. no idea which field the slayer level is stored in though, sorry mate.

Read full topic
item.source: Can some1 explain this to me?

item.title: Can some1 explain this to me?
item.dc:creator: @iisayboom2 iisayboom2
item.description:
@iisayboom2 wrote:

Okey so i wanna make a better slayer system. Look at this.

public void giveTask() {
if (c.combatLevel < 50)
giveTask(1);
else if (c.combatLevel >= 50 && c.combatLevel <= 90)
giveTask(2);
else if (c.combatLevel > 90 && c.combatLevel <= 121)
giveTask(3);
else if (c.combatLevel >= 122 && c.combatLevel <= 138)
giveTask(4);
else
giveTask(2);
}

Like you see it is only navigated on combatlevel. My question is if i could make it so it looks at the combatlevel and the slayer level.

I was think about something like if (c.combatLevel < 50 && ???).
The ??? means that i dunno how to write it down like slayer <= 50 or something.

Read full topic
item.source: Can some1 explain this to me?
